abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the National Agricultural
            Research and Extension Project for Guinea was satisfactory.
            The project achieved most of its objectives, institutional
            development was partially achieved, sustainability is
            likely, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower
            was satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, a project design which combines research and
            extension within one agricultural services project, such as
            in NAREP, is more likely to succeed if it builds on the
            synergy of the two services. Second, the institutional
            relationship between research and extension needs to be
            clarified early on so that one service does not overshadow
            the other. Third, the Bank needs to assess more
            realistically the Borrower's capacity to provide
            counterpart funds in a timely manner. Finally, the Bank
            should be more even-handed in its supervision of project components.
